nodes.title: Green Nodes
widgets_values: Stuff you want to change often. The "main controls", if you will.

nodes.title: Purple Nodes
widgets_values: Conditional nodes that you may want to disable
Adjust lightx2\ning LoRA if you want to.

nodes.title: Last High Noise Step (usually half Steps)
Last High Noise Step (usually half Steps)
Red Nodes
widgets_values:
Important, and not generally changed: 
CLIP / VAE / Negative Prompt / Advanced WanVideo nodes

nodes.title: Note: CLIP Models
widgets_values:
| Rank | Text Encoder | Strengths | When to Use / Trade-offs |
|---|---|---|---|
| **1** | `umt5_xxl_fp16` | Highest fidelity among the three; better detail, more stable text encoding; fewer quantization artifacts. | Use when you have enough VRAM and want the best quality. Ideal for intricate prompts, small text, or detailed scenes. |
| **2** | `umt5_xxl_enc_bf16` | Very close to FP16 in many cases; good dynamic range; often a bit lighter on memory/compute compared to FP16. | Good compromise when FP16 is pushing limits of memory or speed but you still want strong quality. |
| **3** | `umt5_xxl_fp8_e4m3fn_scaled` | Smallest memory footprint; “scaled” helps reduce some FP8 loss; still decent quality if you can accept slight degradation. | Use when memory or speed constraints make FP16/BF16 difficult; acceptable for many tasks where subtle precision is less critical. |

nodes.title: Note: Model Precision
widgets_values:
| Format / Mode | Bit Width / Structure | Rank (Higher → Lower Precision) | Advantages / When Good | Disadvantages / Trade-offs |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Base Precision Formats** | | | | |
| FP32 | 32-bit float | **1 (highest)** | Very high accuracy; large dynamic range; minimal numerical issues. | High VRAM, slower compute. |
| BF16 | 16-bit float (same exponent bits as FP32, fewer mantissa) | **2** | Close dynamic range to FP32; good trade-off of precision vs memory. | Less fraction precision; possible rounding errors. |
| FP16 | 16-bit float (IEEE half precision) | **3** | Much lower memory; good speed; widely supported. | Less dynamic range; more risk of underflow/overflow; less precision. |
| **Quantization / FP8 / Lower Precision Variants** | | | | |
| FP8 E4M3 (scaled, non-fast / "fp8_e4m3fn_scaled") | 8-bit float: 1 sign, 4 exponent bits, 3 mantissa | **4** | Better precision for small values; useful detail close to zero; decent dynamic range. | Lower dynamic range; need calibration / scaling; possibly slower if fallback. |
| FP8 E5M2 (scaled) | 8-bit float: 1 sign, 5 exponent bits, 2 mantissa | **5** | More dynamic range (can handle bigger/smaller extremes) with some calibration; less error in wide distribution. | Less precision in mantissa; subtle detail around small values may be lost. |
| FP8 E4M3 / E5M2 (fast / non-scaled) | Same structures but with fewer calibrations / optimizations | **6** | Faster; less memory / compute overhead; may still be usable. | More quantization error; possible artifacts; more numerical instability. |
| Q8 / Int8 (integer quantization) | 8-bit integer (no floating exponent) | **7 (lowest)** | Very compact; often fastest; works well if perfect fidelity not required. | Significant loss of precision; limited dynamic range; visible errors in many cases. |

# The Codex
## A Library of notes collected from other workflows.

nodes.title: Note: Variability
widgets_values:
The kSampler node, the resolution, the LoRA's, the diffusion model, the clip model, the prompt, the CFG.

The seed too, obviously, but it's one of the factors you have more control over when attempting to make changes.

The prompt is often quite sensitive to change, small changes can be made, but often even a word or two can make a big change in the results.

I want to call out the sampler node specifically, because it's not something you may have considered, but each sampler is implemented differently and introduces changes. For example, using the ClownsharKsampler will give completely different results than the Ksampler node, even with the same settings.

nodes.title: Note: Length
widgets_values:
The further past 5 seconds you go, the weirder your video might get, and the less dynamic it will seem. Wan is generally trained on 5 second clips, so the best looking clips will be 5 seconds, generally. (Not always true, of course.) Issues with color, quality, and prompt adherance are likely to emerge the further above 5 you go. 

The slider in this workflow stops at 10 seconds for that reason; not only does do longer videos take more proprotional time, but they get worse.

nodes.title: Note: "Quality"
widgets_values:
Quality comes from steps / sampler for t2v. For i2v, you get to cheat a bit because a very high quality input image for a start frame will help improve the overall quality of the results with less steps.

Poor LoRA quality and LoRA conflicts can lower quality.

Quality can also be improved by choosing a more common aspect ratio.

nodes.title: Wan 2.2 Prompt Keywords and Phrases
widgets_values:
[https://wan-22.toolbomber.com/](https://wan-22.toolbomber.com/)

Camera descriptions work best in landscape mode. The effects are less strong in vertical frames.

### Camera distance
* extreme close-up shot - eyes only
* close-up shot - head only
* medium shot - head and upper body only
* medium wide shot - medium shot of subject in wide angle frame
* wide shot - shot of subject from a distance
* wide-angle lens - shows more of the scene in a wide, distant shot
* wide lens - similar to wide-angle with slightly distorted wide view

### Camera height / viewpoint
* over-the-shoulder shot - camera is behind one of the people in frame, at shoulder level
* high angle shot - camera is above the subject, looking down at subject
* low angle shot - camera is below eye level of subject, usually about waist height
* extreme low angle shot - camera is below waist level of subject
* dutch angle shot - camera frame is tilted at an angle so left or right side is higher than the other
* aerial shot - camera is high above the subject, at a distance
* eye-level / waist-level / etc. - places camera height relative to subject

### Camera movement
* camera pushes in for a close-up - camera view gets closer to subject
* camera pulls back- camera view pulls away from subject
* camera pans to the right/left - camera strafes right or left while pointing in same direction
* camera tilts up/down - camera stays in place but tilts its view up or down
* tracking shot - camera moves with the subject to preserve framing
* arc shot - camera rotates around the subject, keeping subject in frame
* handheld camera - camera is shaky and unsteady, moving wildly during scene

### Lighting
* edge lighting - edges of objects are highlighted
* top lighting / side lighting / underlighting - where is the light source relative to subject
* silhouette lighting - light is behind subject, subject is a dark sillhouette
* low contrast lighting - lighting is balanced across the whole frame
* high contrast lighting - some parts of frame are much lighter or darker than others
* dawn/sunrise/afternoon/night time - dictates color and warmth of light
* hard lighting - details are in sharp relief because of lighting
* soft lighting - details are smoothed with softer light effect
* overcast lighting - low contrast, less color saturation
* moonlight - dim, cool color lighting
* daylight - bright sunshing lighting, also use "sunny lighting"

### Colors
* warm colors - trending towards reds, oranges, yellows, more intense colors
* cool colors - trending towards blues, greys, muted colors
* saturated colors - more intense, vibrant colors
* desaturated colors - less intense colors with a more even tone

nodes.title: Note: Update LoRA's
widgets_values:
press r: 
You can update the the LoRA's and models available without browser refreshing ComfyUI.

nodes.title: Note: FP16 Accumulation?
widgets_values: This workflow doesn't use FP16 accumulation. With the prevalence of self-forcing, further "compression" to the calculation space is not something I am crazy about. I need to test it more, but I haven't loved the issues I've seen in what I've done. It would be easy to add here if you want maximum speed tho.

nodes.title: Note: WanVideo?
widgets_values: This is an alternate version of my workflow that makes a number of changes in order to support the WanVideo nodes. This set of nodes imlements a completely different sampler workflow that produces very different results. Often, I have found these to be of higher quality on average, but this implementation can also slower. Lightx2/ning still works, but a bit slower when on. This is a simple translation of the example implementation. It's a powerful alternative workflow, but more complex. So I wanted to bring my UI over to enable fpolks to try it out while preserving the same concepts of my workflow supporting the more traditional samplers.

nodes.title: Note: What? Is? This?
widgets_values: lightx2\ning are a way to enable faster 4-step generations. These come at the cost of prompy adherance and expressive capability: using these will reduce what Wan 2.2 is capable of, but in exchange you'll still see very good results and more of them! I recommend keeping this on, but you should also try turning it off sometime to understand some of the infinite well of differences.

nodes.title: Note: Which version?
widgets_values: There are many versions of these accelerators that are worth exploring. Each version gives you a different look and results. You'll find some combinations of models and speed LoRA's work better than others.

nodes.title: Note: Strength
widgets_values: You can adjust the strengths here. 2:1 is a popular high to low ratio. 1:1 is fine, but 2 in high noise makes it converge faster. I've seen 2.2:0.8 as well. Some argue to never go above 1:1.

nodes.title: Note: Clean VRAM
widgets_values: If you start hitting VRAM errors during long sessions, consider un-bypassing this.
🎨 LoRA's and other settings can cause desaturation, this "Color Correct" node provides a bit of extra compensation. Bypass this if things look accurate.

nodes.title: Note: NAG?
widgets_values: NAG is a technique used to improve negative prompt adherance with self-forcing, because at the required CFG of 1.0, negative prompting is essentially ignored. Less important with CFG scaling, but I'm adding it for now.
🎞️ GIMM-VFI seems to be the fastest interpolater. You should test FILM and RIFE as well. FILM seems to be most popular(?), but is slower.
🔪 i2v can end up over-sharp if the input image was sharp to begin with. Consider bypassing.
A little film grain improves the general impression of video.

nodes.title: Negative Prompt
widgets_values: 色调艳丽，过曝，静态，细节模糊不清，字幕，风格，作品，画作，画面，静止，整体发灰，最差质量，低质量，JPEG压缩残留，丑陋的，残缺的，多余的手指，画得不好的手部，画得不好的脸部，畸形的，毁容的，形态畸形的肢体，手指融合，静止不动的画面，杂乱的背景，三条腿，背景人很多，倒着走

nodes.title: Note: Model Scale
widgets_values: You'll need to adjust the quantization to 'none' and base precision to fp16 if you want to use the full models.

nodes.title: Note:
widgets_values: Some T2V LoRA's only work with the fp8 scaled model.

nodes.title: Note: Image Size
widgets_values: I prefer to think about image ratios, not exact dimensions, but if you want to set a fixed size, un-mute this. (You can ignore the "Width and height from aspect ratio" node if you do - no need to bypass it.)

nodes.title: Note: More on the TripleWVSampler
widgets_values:
So the TripleWVSampler is a single node that's similar to technique where you chain WanVideo Samplers together. The first one is a short burst of high noise step(s). The theory is that this allows WAN to create the inital motion without Lightx2\ning forcing a less dynamic result. This is then passed to another sampler that finishes the high noise pass but with the accelerator applied to speed things up. Finally the normal low noise pass continues also with the accelerator. This sounds easy enough, but getting the math right to make a good image is a bit tricky. It requires a bunch of math nodes to control exactly how many steps happen with each samplere.

You should try unhooking the switching strategy and experiment with changing it, this controls the balance of the self-forced high and low noise steps. It's setup to be optimized for the generic i2v and t2v optimized math, but there are some other choices too.

nodes.title: Note: TripleKSampler CFG
widgets_values: This sampler uses both CFG settings, because the first high noise pass needs a non-Lightx2\ning value
WanVideo has a special way to improve prompt adherance by scaling the CFG for lightx2/ning over time. The CFG here is for the low noise sampler.p

nodes.title: Positive Prompt
widgets_values: German experessionism. The women in black sparkling evening gowns do a choregraphed dance on a musical film, film studio set, minimalist constructed circular staircase prop, a classic Hollywood film. Busby Berkely style musical, with 30 synchronized dancers in glittering gowns forming geometric patterns under art deco chandeliers. The camera pushes in for an extreme close-up of the woman in front who smiles seductively as she dances and sings. The background is a high concept constructed stage set with strong geometric patterns.

nodes.type: Width and height from aspect ratio 🪴

properties.Node name for S&R: Width and height from aspect ratio 🪴

nodes.title: Note: WanVideo LoRA loaders...
widgets_values: WanVideo handles LoRA's differently. There is no Power Loader node equivaelent. You'll need to select "none" when you want to disable a LoRA. Bypass the WanVideo Lora Select Multi nodes when not being used. I've added two of them for you, but if you need more LoRA's you can clone it and hook up the output of the new one to the input on the bottom one; you can chain as many as you need.

nodes.title: Note: Samplers
widgets_values: You now have access to the TripleWVSampler. This node simplies a complex technique that uses two high noise samplers, but the first one has no lightx2\ning. The theory is that this injects more of Wan's native motion during the initial noise step but is slower. Now you can give it a try! More notes next to the sampler. Only use with Lightx2\ning. Support for WanVideo was recently added, so I've added support for those that want to experiment. This versions runs more slowly.
